conditions.condition: The House of Lords and the House of Commons have distinct compositions and roles within the Parliament of the United Kingdom.
conditions.answer: The House of Lords includes two different types of members: The Lords Spiritual (the senior bishops of the Church of England) and the Lords Temporal (members of the Peerage). Its members are not elected by the population at large. In contrast, the House of Commons is made up of Members of Parliament (MPs), elected to represent constituencies.

conditions.condition: Different jurisdictions have varying electoral systems and voting requirements.
conditions.answer: Victoria uses instant-runoff voting in single-member seats for the Legislative Assembly, and single transferable vote in multi-member seats for the proportionally represented Legislative Council. In contrast, the House of Representatives (New Zealand) has a system where 72 MPs are elected directly in electorates while the remainder of seats are assigned to list MPs based on each party's share of the total party vote.

conditions.condition: Traffic circles direct traffic around a central island.

conditions.condition: Traffic circles reduce delays in certain situations.
conditions.answer: When traffic volumes are relatively equal on intersecting roads, a roundabout can reduce delays by eliminating full stops.
